title: China’s Surveillance State Hits Rare Resistance From Its Own Subjects
abstract: Beijing’s swift move to censor news about one of the largest known data breaches shows keen awareness of how major security lapses can harm its credibility.
byline: By Amy Qin, John Liu and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: Surveillance cameras in the southern city of Shenzhen. China says its expansive surveillance apparatus is necessary for public safety.
Surveillance cameras in the southern city of Shenzhen. China says its expansive surveillance apparatus is necessary for public safety.
Surveillance cameras in the southern city of Shenzhen. China says its expansive surveillance apparatus is necessary for public safety.

title: Facts Were Sparse on an Abortion Case. But That Didn’t Stop the Attacks.
abstract: The story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio became the focus of a heated political debate that played out in the news media.

multimedia.caption: The facts of the case became clearer on Wednesday, when The Columbus Dispatch reported that a man in Ohio had been arraigned in the rape of a 10-year-old girl.
multimedia.copyright: Nick Fancher for The New York Times

title: China’s Economic Growth Slows Sharply as Covid Policy Takes a Toll
abstract: The humming economy has been replaced by high unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending in a year when Beijing is focused on projecting stability.

multimedia.caption: A textile factory in Nantong, China. China’s economy in the second quarter expanded 0.4 percent from a year earlier.
A textile factory in Nantong, China. China’s economy in the second quarter expanded 0.4 percent from a year earlier.
A textile factory in Nantong, China. China’s economy in the second quarter expanded 0.4 percent from a year earlier.

title: The Magic of Your First Work Friends
abstract: Early-career connections can be life-defining. For young people entering the work force today, the connections over Zoom are shaky.

title: U.S. Electric Car Sales Climb Sharply Despite Shortages
abstract: A scarcity of semiconductors and raw materials held back production, but buyers remain enthusiastic.

multimedia.caption: Vehicles that run on batteries, like these at a Tesla store in Brooklyn, accounted for more than 5 percent of new-car sales in June.

title: Amazon Moves to End a Long-Running Antitrust Case in Europe
abstract: The retail giant said it would stop collecting nonpublic data on rivals and give merchants more ways to reach customers.

multimedia.caption: Amazon has been under investigation in Europe for improperly using its dominance in e-commerce to box out competitors.
Amazon has been under investigation in Europe for improperly using its dominance in e-commerce to box out competitors.

title: The Housing Shortage Isn’t Just a Coastal Crisis Anymore
abstract: An increasingly national problem has consequences for the quality of American family life, the economy and the future of housing politics.
byline: By Emily Badger and Eve Washington

title: How to Invest When Inflation Is Bad and a Recession May Loom
abstract: While the news may indicate that the markets and economy are rocky, long-term investors can ride it out with a little luck and a lot of planning, our columnist says.

title: Democrats Face Deepening Peril as Republicans Seize on Inflation Fears
abstract: Economists warn that a blitz of midterm election campaign ads could push consumer prices even higher.

multimedia.caption: Republicans across the country are investing heavily in campaign advertisements that portray a dark sense of economic disarray and blame President Biden and the Democrats for rapid inflation.

title: Bank of America is fined $225 million for mishandling pandemic unemployment benefits.
abstract: An automated fraud filter improperly froze thousands of customers’ accounts, regulators said.

title: A watchdog report absolves financial transactions made by two top Fed officials.
abstract: The Fed’s chair and vice chair did not violate any rules, the report found. Still, some found the description of the vice chair’s trades unsatisfying.

multimedia.caption: Jerome H. Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, asked for an inspector general investigation into financial trades by Fed officials at a moment when the central bank was actively propping up markets.

title: Stripe, the payments start-up, lowers internal valuation 28 percent.
abstract: A sell-off of tech stocks in the public markets has prompted private start-ups to evaluate whether their soaring valuations over the past two years will hold up.

multimedia.caption: Stripe was founded in 2010 by the entrepreneurs and brothers John and Patrick Collison.

title: Barbara Kruger: A Way With Words
abstract: She created some of the most memorable works of her era. Now the activist-artist is back with two immersive shows, at MoMA and David Zwirner Gallery.

title: A Fed Governor Signals a Full-Point Rate Increase Is Possible, but Not Yet His Call
abstract: Christopher Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, could support an even bigger July rate increase than the Fed’s large June move if economic data continue to come in hot.

multimedia.caption: “Inflation has to be our focus, every meeting and every day,” Christopher Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said in a speech.

abstract: Ms. Reed, who joined The Intercept in 2015, will start in the fall.

title: Stocks edge lower as bank earnings add to concerns about the economy.
abstract: Companies in the United States are starting to report their earnings for the second quarter, a chance for investors to assess how hard businesses are being hit by economic headwinds.

title: The S.E.C. broadens its inquiry into Elon Musk’s disclosures about Twitter.
abstract: The agency questioned whether a tweet Mr. Musk sent in May about the acquisition of Twitter should have been disclosed to the agency and investors.

title: Big Banks Prepare for Downturn, but Don’t See Recession Yet
abstract: As profits slowed at Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase, executives said that lending to consumers and businesses remained healthy but that risks loomed “down the road.”
byline: By Emily Flitter and Stephen Gandel

multimedia.caption: Inflation and market turmoil are weighing on JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s largest bank.

abstract: Tell us about your experience with work friendships when you’re not in the office.

title: Twitter suffers a global outage at a delicate moment for the company.
abstract: The social networking site went offline on Thursday morning, affecting users worldwide. The interruption comes as the company is fighting Elon Musk over a proposed acquisition.

title: Biden, Oil and the Middle East
abstract: Under pressure as tight oil supplies hurt the U.S. economy, Biden will go to Saudi Arabia for a meeting with M.B.S.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross

title: Janet Yellen Says It’s in Russia’s Interest to Go Along With an Oil Price Cap
abstract: Facing sanctions on its exports, Russia could continue selling oil profitably under a cap, the U.S. Treasury secretary said, while global strains on supply and pressure on prices would reduce.

multimedia.caption: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has had “negative spillover effects” for the global economy, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said at a Group of 20 summit in Bali, Indonesia.
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has had “negative spillover effects” for the global economy, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said at a Group of 20 summit in Bali, Indonesia.

title: Toronto Steps Into Summer
abstract: It’s the city’s traditional high season and it is celebrating with newly opened hotels and restaurants and a revived live-performance scene.

title: Delta flew a plane from Heathrow to the U.S. just to deliver 1,000 pieces of stranded luggage.
abstract: The London airport’s capacity troubles because of staff shortages and soaring demand have contributed to delays, cancellations and lost bags.

title: Drug-Resistant Infections in Hospitals Soared During the Pandemic, C.D.C. Says
abstract: A new report says the havoc wrought by the coronavirus reversed gains made by health care facilities to combat deadly pathogens.

title: Novavax’s latecomer Covid-19 vaccine gets U.S. authorization.
abstract: The vaccine was authorized as a primary immunization series for adults, rather than a booster, which may limit its market at first.
byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Carl Zimmer

title: Netflix turns to Microsoft to help build its new ad-supported service.
abstract: The streaming giant hopes a less expensive offering will boost subscription numbers, which have dropped for the first time in a decade.

title: Inflation Soared in June, Pinching Consumers and Challenging Policymakers
abstract: Prices climbed 9.1 percent from a year earlier, ramping up pressure on the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates.

title: Gas Prices, a Big Inflation Factor, Are Coming Down Sharply
abstract: A four-week decline has offered some relief to drivers. Weather, war and demand will influence how long the decline lasts.

multimedia.caption: Gasoline prices have declined 28 days in a row, the longest decline since the collapse in energy demand in early 2020.

title: Gates Foundation Adds $20 Billion to Its Coffers
abstract: The organization, still run by Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, will eventually spend $9 billion a year, up from $6 billion, on causes like global health and education.

abstract: A rebranding and a new documentary have the lingerie company back in the cultural cross hairs.

title: Euro Falls to Equal the U.S. Dollar for the First Time in 20 Years
abstract: In recent months, pressure on the euro has been mounting while investors have been flocking to the U.S. dollar, a haven in times of economic upheaval.

title: Airlines’ Challenge Is Cutting Costs, Not Filling Seats
abstract: U.S. carriers see no slowdown in demand, despite unease about the economy. But problems with staffing and operations are eating into profits.

multimedia.caption: Delta Air Lines forecast that revenue from July through September would exceed revenue from the same period in 2019.
Delta Air Lines forecast that revenue from July through September would exceed revenue from the same period in 2019.

title: Twitter Unloads on Musk
abstract: The company contends that Musk breached his agreement to buy it by not using “reasonable best efforts” to close the deal, and so has no right to bail out.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
